questions.text: A 52-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after the onset of weakness in her right arm, leg, and face. Her husband says that she was finishing her breakfast when suddenly her right leg and arm “stopped working properly.” She tried to talk to him but her speech was incoherent. For the past 4 months, she has been more anxious than usual and experienced dizziness on several occasions. She used to exercise regularly but had to give up her exercise routine 3 months ago because of generalized fatigue, and lightheadedness and shortness of breath with exertion. She has a history of hypertension. She takes lisinopril daily and alprazolam as needed. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She is a tax accountant and has had increased stress at work recently. On presentation, she is alert and fully oriented; her speech is normal. The patient's pants are soaked with urine. On neurologic examination, she has a slight right facial droop and 4/5 muscle strength in the right arm and leg. Sensation is slightly diminished over the right side of the face and right arm and leg. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Irregularly irregular R-R intervals on electrocardiogram
Ruptured saccular aneurysm on CT angiography of the head
Double lumen of the left-sided carotid artery on duplex ultrasound
Intraparenchymal hyperdensity on CT scan of the head

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Irregularly irregular rhythm and absent P waves on ECG are characteristic of atrial fibrillation (Afib). Although the classic signs of Afib include tachycardia and an irregularly irregular pulse, some individuals are asymptomatic or present only with subtle signs of arrhythmia (e.g., palpitations, dizziness, lightheadedness, fatigue, and dyspnea). The uncoordinated atrial contractions lead to blood stasis in the left atrium and atrial appendage, which significantly increases the risk of clot formation and thromboembolic complications. Dislodged emboli can clog several different arteries simultaneously and result in embolic ischemic stroke. Individuals with embolic stroke typically experience maximum severity of symptoms at onset, followed by rapid improvement if the emboli migrate outward allowing arterial recanalization. Embolic stroke from a cardiac source often affects young or middle-aged people with cardiac disease, whereas thrombotic or embolic stroke due to atherosclerosis is more common in older adults with risk factors for atherosclerosis.

The CHA2DS2-VASc score is used to calculate the risk of stroke in patients with Afib. This patient's score is 2 points (female sex, history of hypertension), which puts her at intermediate risk for stroke.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Irregularly irregular rhythm (examples of the irregular R-R intervals are indicated by red arrows)

– Average ventricular rate ∼ 84/min (14 QRS complexes can be seen on the 10-second rhythm strip)

– No discernable P waves

– Narrow QRS complexes (examples indicated by green lines)

– Normal cardiac axis

These findings are characteristic of atrial fibrillation.

B) INCORRECT:

A ruptured saccular aneurysm resulting in subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) leads to hemorrhagic stroke. SAH classically manifests with severe headaches (often described by patients as the worst headache they have ever experienced) with a hyperacute onset, other meningeal signs, and symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., nausea, vomiting) in addition to focal neurological deficits. In patients with hemorrhagic stroke, these deficits typically worsen as the hematoma expands. In this patient whose symptoms have rapidly improved, an embolic stroke, not a hemorrhagic stroke, is more likely; therefore, another finding would be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Valvular vegetations on transthoracic echocardiography are characteristic of bacterial endocarditis (BE), which can cause septic embolization and result in an embolic stroke. Subacute BE can manifest with lightheadedness and dyspnea on exertion for weeks to months. However, most patients with BE present with constitutional symptoms, as well as extracardiac manifestations, such as petechiae, splinter hemorrhages, Janeway lesions, Osler nodes, and/or Roth spots. In addition, BE typically develops in patients with a history of structural cardiac disease (e.g., rheumatic heart disease, aortic stenosis), prosthetic valves, IV drug use, intravascular devices (e.g., IV catheter), or poor dental hygiene.

D) INCORRECT:

A double lumen of the left-sided carotid artery on duplex ultrasound is consistent with carotid artery dissection (CAD), which can lead to ischemic stroke. However, nonischemic features due to expanding hematoma would be expected, such as ipsilateral headache, facial/neck pain, Horner syndrome, and/or tinnitus. Finally, CAD is typically caused by penetrating or blunt trauma, which this patient has no history of.

E) INCORRECT:

An intraparenchymal hyperdensity on head CT suggests intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH). Given this patient's history of hypertension, the index of suspicion for spontaneous ICH should be high. However, ICH causes hemorrhagic stroke typically manifesting with headaches (caused by meningeal irritation/traction) and symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., nausea, vomiting) in addition to focal neurological deficits. In patients with hemorrhagic stroke, these deficits typically worsen as the hematoma expands. In this patient whose symptoms have rapidly improved, an embolic stroke, not a hemorrhagic stroke, is more likely; therefore, another finding would be expected.
questions.hint: Right-sided weakness and numbness in the upper and lower limbs, urinary incontinence, and aphasia (incoherent speech) suggest stroke affecting several different vascular territories: the left anterior cerebral artery and left middle cerebral artery. These features in combination with rapid clinical improvement after symptom onset suggest a specific etiology of stroke, which is further supported by the history of fatigue, exertional dyspnea, and lightheadedness.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because of intermittent episodes of heart palpitations for 3 weeks. The palpitations are accompanied by chest pain that is sharp and localized to the left 3rd intercostal space. The patient does not smoke. She drinks one to two glasses of wine on the weekends. She appears nervous. Her pulse is 110/min and irregularly irregular, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. Examination shows a fine tremor on both hands and digital swelling. There is retraction of the left upper eyelid. A systolic ejection murmur is heard along the right upper sternal border. The extremities are warm, and pulses are 2+ bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Propylthiouracil (PTU) is an antithyroid drug that is used in the medical treatment of hyperthyroidism, which this patient shows signs and symptoms of. However, PTU is usually indicated during the first trimester of pregnancy, whereas methimazole is usually the preferred antithyroid drug for most other cases because of its long duration of action and potency. Moreover, this patient should receive immediate control of her symptoms.

B) CORRECT:

Beta blockers (e.g., propranolol) are indicated for the immediate control of symptoms in patients with hyperthyroidism. This patient with anxiety, tremor, digital swelling, retraction of the eyelid, and irregular heartbeats most likely has hyperthyroidism. Thyroid hormones affect cardiac myocytes directly and also stimulate the proliferation of beta-adrenergic receptors, which can cause cardiac arrhythmias as seen in this patient. Beta blockers decrease the adrenergic tone and therefore reduce tachycardia, control hypertension, improve muscle weakness, tremor, and neuropsychiatric symptoms. Propranolol, in high doses, also decreases the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 by inhibiting the 5'-monodeiodinase enzyme. Thus, this patient should be started on a beta blocker, preferably propranolol, as soon as possible.

C) INCORRECT:

Main indications for digoxin treatment are atrial fibrillation (AF) and heart failure in treatment-resistant cases. Although this patient has an arrhythmia, which could be AF, it is accompanied by symptoms of thyrotoxicosis (tremor, anxiety, retraction of the eyelid). Hyperthyroid AF is usually resistant to the typical dose of digoxin, which requires a larger dose and thereby increases the risk of digoxin toxicity. Moreover, digoxin does not provide relief from the other manifestations of adrenergic hyperstimulation.

D) INCORRECT:

Amiodarone is used in the treatment of ventricular tachycardia and persisting ventricular fibrillation after unsuccessful defibrillation, as well as the long-term treatment of refractory supraventricular arrhythmia (e.g., atrial fibrillation). Because of the high levels of iodine in amiodarone, it may aggravate preexisting thyroid conditions. In this patient, who shows symptoms of supraventricular arrhythmia (palpitations and irregularly irregular pulse) and hyperthyroidism (anxiety, tremor, digital swelling, and retraction of the eyelid), amiodarone should only be considered if other treatment options fail.

E) INCORRECT:

Warfarin is an oral anticoagulant. Patients with atrial fibrillation (AF) are at increased risk of developing thromboembolic complications, which is why long-term anticoagulation is indicated when CHA2DS2-VASc score is ≥ 3 in women or when AF is caused by valvular disease. This patient's CHA2DS2-VASc score is 1 and although she presents with symptoms of AF (irregularly irregular pulse) and a systolic ejection murmur, her murmur is most likely due to the hyperdynamic circulation resulting from the increased adrenergic tone.

F) INCORRECT:

Diltiazem is classified as a class IV antiarrhythmic drug and is used to achieve rate control in patients with atrial fibrillation (AF), which is this patient's most likely arrhythmia. However, another therapeutic option is more commonly used and would also relieve thyrotoxic symptoms, such as tremor and anxiety.
questions.hint: The condition underlying this patient's arrhythmia can also cause heat intolerance, weight loss, and diarrhea.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of retrosternal chest pain. He describes it as 7 out of 10 in intensity. He has coronary artery disease, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His current medications are aspirin, simvastatin, metformin, and enalapril. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 33 years. On arrival, his pulse is 115/min and irregular, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 85/55 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. An ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diltiazem is first-line therapy for relieving symptoms and achieving rate control in patients with Afib who are hemodynamically stable. While this patient does have findings of acute Afib on his ECG, he is hypotensive and reports chest pain, both of which are signs of hemodynamic instability.

B) INCORRECT:

A coronary angiogram is indicated in the acute setting for patients with myocardial infarction (MI) who are being evaluated for emergency coronary artery revascularization with surgery or angioplasty. Although this patient has severe chest pain and hypotension that may be consistent with MI, focal ST segment elevations in contiguous ECG leads would be expected in MI.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

- Sinus rhythm with a heart rate of ∼ 85/min
- Normal cardiac axis (leads I, II, and III positive, but difficult to interpret because of the ST changes)
- ST elevation in V2–V6, aVL, and slightly in I
- Reciprocal ST depression in leads II, III, and aVF

C) INCORRECT:

Esmolol is an appropriate first-line therapy to relieve symptoms and achieve rate control in patients with Afib who are hemodynamically stable. While this patient does have findings of acute Afib on his ECG, he is hypotensive and reports severe chest pain, both of which are signs of hemodynamic instability.

D) INCORRECT:

Amiodarone is an appropriate treatment for hemodynamically stable ventricular tachycardia (VT). While this patient's chest pain and hypotension could be caused by VT, ECG findings of VT include wide complex tachycardia, with three or more consecutive premature ventricular beats (i.e., a widened QRS interval) at a heart rate > 120 bpm. Although amiodarone is more commonly used as a rhythm control agent, it can also be used for rate control in patients with stable Afib, but only if first-line (beta blockers or calcium channel blockers) and second-line (digoxin) rate control strategies have failed.
Image Description:

Single-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Rate: 192/min
– Regular rhythm
– No P or T waves are discernible because of the high ventricular rate.
– QRS complexes are broad (> 120 ms) and monomorphic (there is a similar QRS morphology in all beats).

These features are characteristic of monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT). VT persisting for ≥ 30 seconds is considered sustained VT (this strip does not show the full 30-second interval).

E) CORRECT:

Unstable Afib, as seen in this patient, should be managed with immediate electrical synchronized cardioversion. Older patients with underlying heart disease (such as this 63-year-old man with coronary artery disease) are at increased risk of hemodynamic compromise. Signs of hemodynamic instability include hypotension, confusion, symptoms of heart failure (e.g., dyspnea), and chest pain. The goal of synchronized cardioversion is to terminate Afib and thereby restore hemodynamic stability as well as prevent further progression to ventricular tachycardia or ventricular fibrillation. Synchronized cardioversion can also be considered for hemodynamically stable patients with acute onset of Afib (within the past 48 hours).

F) INCORRECT:

Radiofrequency ablation is a possible second-line measure for achieving rhythm control in stable Afib. While this patient does have findings of acute Afib on his ECG, he is hypotensive and reports severe chest pain, both of which are signs of hemodynamic instability. Even if he were stable, first-line treatment would be conducted before ablation.

G) INCORRECT:

Defibrillation or unsynchronized electrical cardioversion is the best initial therapy for patients with ventricular fibrillation (Vfib) or pulseless ventricular tachycardia (also known as shockable rhythms) and is administered alongside cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR). While this patient has no visible P waves on ECG, he has a palpable pulse and QRS complexes are identifiable on ECG, which would not be the case in Vfib. Unlike synchronized cardioversion, defibrillation delivers an electric shock that is not synchronous with the QRS complex, and defibrillation of a patient in Afib (with intact QRS complexes) may actually induce Vfib.
questions.hint: The ECG shows a narrow complex irregular tachycardia with no visible P waves consistent with atrial fibrillation (Afib). Because the patient also has chest pain and hypotension, it is considered an unstable arrhythmia.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of intermittent palpitations. She is a junior in college, and the symptoms began when she returned to her dormitory after a 4-hour bus trip from home. The palpitations have worsened since then and occur more frequently. She does not have any chest pain or shortness of breath. The patient has smoked 5 cigarettes daily for the past 3 years. She drinks 4–6 alcoholic beverages with friends on weekends and tried marijuana once in her freshman year. She is sexually active with her boyfriend and takes an oral contraceptive pill. She is in no apparent distress. Her pulse is 102/min and irregular, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 140/70 mm Hg. The pupils are 4 mm bilaterally and reactive to light. Physical examination shows a fine tremor in both hands and warm extremities. There is 1+ nonpitting bilateral pretibial edema. Lungs are clear to auscultation. An ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

All patients with new-onset symptomatic Afib should be evaluated for potential causes of arrhythmia. Measurement of serum TSH levels is the best initial step in the diagnosis of hyperthyroidism, a common cause of symptomatic Afib that can manifest with hypertension with wide pulse pressure (140/70 mm Hg), tremor, and warm skin. Individuals with Graves disease, the most common cause of hyperthyroidism, can also develop pretibial myxedema, which manifests as nonpitting bilateral pretibial edema. Given that this patient has classic features of hyperthyroidism and Graves disease, her TSH levels should be measured at this time.

Treatment of hyperthyroidism (e.g., with antithyroid drugs and/or surgery) in patients who have developed Afib usually results in conversion to sinus rhythm. Beta-blockers such as propranolol can be administered to reduce the heart rate and provide symptomatic relief. Electrical or pharmacological cardioversion is a last-resort treatment in patients who still have Afib after achieving euthyroid status.

B) INCORRECT:

Expectant management may be considered in patients with paroxysmal Afib, which can be due to stress or excess coffee or alcohol intake and typically resolves without treatment. This patient's hypertension with wide pulse pressure, tremor, warm skin, and pretibial edema suggests a reversible cause of Afib, which requires further evaluation.

C) INCORRECT:

In patients with Afib lasting > 48 hours who have received anticoagulation therapy for less than 3 weeks, transesophageal echocardiography is recommended to rule out atrial thrombus before cardioversion. Although rhythm control with cardioversion may be appropriate for some individuals with Afib, this patient's clinical features suggest a reversible cause of the condition. Identifying and treating the underlying cause of this patient's Afib is likely to result in conversion to sinus rhythm without the need for further interventions.

Transthoracic rather than transesophageal echocardiography should be considered in all patients with new-onset Afib to assess cardiac function and rule out underlying structural heart disease.

D) INCORRECT:

CT pulmonary angiography (CTPA) is indicated in patients with suspected pulmonary embolism (PE) who are stable and have a high pretest probability of PE. This patient has a number of risk factors for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), and thus PE, including smoking, use of the contraceptive pill, and a recent long bus trip. However, with a Wells score for PE of 1.5 (tachycardia), which indicates a low pretest probability of PE, measurement of D-dimers rather than CTPA would be indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Urine toxicology screening is used to confirm the presence of drugs. Intoxication with cocaine or amphetamines may lead to cardiac arrhythmias such as acute Afib. While this patient presents with a tachycardic arrhythmia, tremor in both hands, and warm extremities, she does not have other features of sympathomimetic drug intoxication such as mydriasis or euphoria. Moreover, hypertension with wide pulse pressure and bilateral nonpitting pretibial edema suggests a different cause of Afib.
questions.hint: The absence of P waves and the presence of irregular RR intervals on ECG indicate atrial fibrillation (Afib).

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain and muscle weakness in her right lower leg for 3 hours. Medical history is remarkable for rheumatic mitral valve stenosis, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin, hydrochlorothiazide, and lisinopril. Her pulse is 88/min and irregularly irregular, and her blood pressure is 135/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a cool and pale right leg with delayed capillary filling. Muscle strength and tone in the right calf and foot are decreased. Femoral pulses are present bilaterally. Pedal pulses are absent on the right. Inhibition of which of the following would have most likely prevented this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

P2Y12 receptor antagonists (e.g., clopidogrel) inhibit platelet aggregation and are indicated in the management of acute myocardial infarction and secondary prevention of cardiac events after percutaneous coronary intervention and/or stenting. These agents are not used to prevent thromboembolism in patients with Afib.

B) CORRECT:

Long-term anticoagulation is indicated in women with Afib who have a CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥ 3. This therapy prevents atrial thrombus formation and subsequent thromboembolic events (e.g., acute limb ischemia, stroke). This patient has a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 4 (history of hypertension, history of diabetes, age 65–74 years, female sex) and a HAS-BLED score of 1, excluding contraindications for anticoagulation therapy. Given this patient's history of mitral valve stenosis, warfarin (a vitamin K epoxide reductase inhibitor) is the preferred anticoagulant.

C) INCORRECT:

Nondihydropyridine channel blockers, such as verapamil, inhibit L-type calcium channels and can be used to control heart rate in patients with Afib. However, calcium channel blockers are not used to prevent atrial thrombus formation and subsequent thromboembolic events.

D) INCORRECT:

Aspirin inhibits the synthesis of prostaglandins through irreversible inhibition of the cyclooxygenase enzyme. Aspirin is sometimes used to reduce the risk of thromboembolic events in patients with Afib but is not as effective as another treatment. It may be considered if patients cannot tolerate first-line agents due to bleeding risks, which is not the case here.

E) INCORRECT:

Beta blockers, such as metoprolol, inhibit beta-adrenergic receptors of the sympathetic nervous system and can be used to control fast heart rate in patients with Afib. However, beta blockers do not prevent atrial thrombus formation and subsequent thromboembolic events.
questions.hint: This patient presents with signs of acute limb ischemia. Her irregularly irregular pulse and history of rheumatic mitral valve stenosis suggest that atrial fibrillation (Afib) is the most likely cause.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a 5-year history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He has had episodic palpitations over the past week. His only medication is a tiotropium-formoterol inhaler. His pulse is 140/min and irregular, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 116/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 95%. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Serum concentrations of electrolytes, thyroid-stimulating hormone, and cardiac troponins are within the reference range. An ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Synchronized cardioversion is a first-line treatment option for rhythm control in patients with unstable Afib and patients who have been in Afib for < 48 hours. This patient is hemodynamically stable and his one-week history of intermittent palpitations indicates that he has likely been in Afib for > 48 hours, increasing his risk of developing an atrial thrombus. To avoid triggering a thromboembolic event with cardioversion, additional steps need to be taken before attempting rhythm control. In addition, this patient is currently tachycardic and would initially benefit most greatly from rate control to prevent the new onset of symptoms and long-term atrial remodeling.

B) INCORRECT:

Radiofrequency ablation is an invasive treatment reserved for patients in whom rhythm control by cardioversion has been unsuccessful. It is also conducted in individuals with paroxysmal Afib. In this patient with tachycardic Afib, a different step should be conducted at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

Procainamide therapy is used as an alternative to electrical cardioversion (e.g., if sedation should be avoided) to pharmacologically cardiovert patients to sinus rhythm. This patient with a one-week history of intermittent palpitations has likely been in Afib for > 48 hours, increasing his risk for developing an atrial thrombus. To avoid triggering a thromboembolic event with cardioversion, additional steps need to be taken before attempting rhythm control. Moreover, this patient is currently tachycardic and would initially benefit most greatly from rate control to prevent the new onset of symptoms and long-term atrial remodeling.

D) CORRECT:

Nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers such as verapamil are a first-line option for ventricular rate control in patients with stable Afib. This patient's normal TSH, electrolyte, and troponin levels rule out reversible or treatable causes of Afib. Since this patient is symptomatic with intermittent palpitations and tachycardia, the next appropriate step is rate control. The target resting heart rate for patients with Afib is < 110/min for asymptomatic patients and < 80/min for symptomatic patients. Furthermore, the need for anticoagulation should be evaluated in all patients with Afib. Cardioversion can be considered as an alternative to rate control, but this procedure carries a high risk of thromboembolism. Therefore, patients like this one who have been in Afib for > 48 hours should receive prophylactic anticoagulation therapy for 3 weeks before cardioversion. This period can be shortened if atrial thrombi are excluded by transesophageal echocardiography.

E) INCORRECT:

Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is indicated to rule out an atrial thrombus prior to cardioversion in patients with Afib for > 48 hours if cardioversion is attempted earlier than after three weeks of anticoagulation. This patient with a one-week history of intermittent palpitations has likely been in Afib for > 48 hours and cardioversion could be considered. However, since he is hemodynamically stable and currently tachycardic, rate control is recommended first to prevent the recurrence of symptoms and long-term atrial remodeling.

F) INCORRECT:

Propranolol is a first-line treatment for rate control in patients with symptomatic, tachycardic Afib, which is seen here. However, as a nonselective beta antagonist, propranolol is contraindicated in patients with COPD. The blocking of β2-receptors causes smooth muscle contraction in the lung, i.e., bronchoconstriction, which can exacerbate preexisting pulmonary conditions such as COPD and asthma.
questions.hint: The ECG shows absent P waves, an irregularly irregular tachycardic rhythm, and narrow QRS complexes (indicating supraventricular tachycardia). These are all signs of atrial fibrillation (Afib). Some pulmonary diseases, such as COPD, pulmonary embolism, and pneumonia, are risk factors for developing Afib. Although this patient has palpitations, he has no ischemia, hemodynamic compromise, or altered mental status, which means he has stable Afib.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 5-day history of intermittent palpitations. She has no history of syncope or chest pain. She had similar symptoms one year ago and following workup has been treated with daily flecainide since then. She drinks one to two glasses of wine on the weekends. She does not smoke. Her pulse is 71/min and her blood pressure is 134/72 mm Hg. A complete blood count shows no abnormalities. Serum creatinine, electrolytes, and TSH are within normal limits. An ECG is shown. Ablation near which of the following sites would be most appropriate for long-term management of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Alcohol septal ablation of the basal interventricular septum can be used to relieve severe left ventricular outflow tract obstruction in patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). Patients with HCM are at increased risk of developing tachyarrhythmias, which, in symptomatic cases, manifest with intermittent palpitations. However, there is no electrocardiographic evidence of HCM such as left ventricular hypertrophy (e.g., left-axis deviation; QRS complex ≥ 4.5 mV in at least one precordial lead; S wave in V1 or V2 + R wave in V5 or V6 ≥ 3.5 mV; R wave in aVL ≥ 1.1 mV; R wave in lead I ≥ 1.2 mV; R wave in aVF ≥ 2.0 mV).
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Heart rate: ∼55/min
– Regular sinus rhythm
– Normal cardiac axis: positive (+) QRS complex polarity in leads I, II, and III
– Broad and bifid P waves (P): referred to as “P mitrale” and suggestive of left atrial enlargement
– SV2 (S) + RV5 (R) >3.5 mV: meets Sokolow-Lyon criteria for left ventricular hypertrophy
– Left ventricular strain pattern: ST depression (ST) with T-wave inversion (T) in left-sided leads I and V4–V6

Positive Sokolow-Lyon criteria and left ventricular strain pattern are characteristic of left ventricular hypertrophy.

B) CORRECT:

Automatic depolarizing foci near the pulmonary vein are typically involved in the pathogenesis of atrial fibrillation. Ablation of atrial tissue around the pulmonary veins (pulmonary vein isolation) would prevent these depolarizing foci from spreading to the rest of the myocardium.

C) INCORRECT:

AV nodal ablation can be used to treat Afib. However, a patient who undergoes AV nodal ablation will require cardiac pacing for life. Therefore, ablation of a site that does not necessitate permanent cardiac pacing is usually preferred for young adults with Afib. Rather, AV nodal ablation is typically performed in older patients with Afib and patients with Afib and tachycardia-induced cardiomyopathy or congestive heart failure.

D) INCORRECT:

The cavotricuspid isthmus is the most commonly ablated site to treat atrial flutter. Although atrial flutter can result in intermittent palpitations, ECG typically shows a regular rhythm and a saw-tooth pattern of P waves (flutter waves). A different site is ablated to treat Afib.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 50 mm/s)

- Atrial rate ~280/min; ventricular rate ~70/min (4:1 conduction)
- Normal cardiac axis
- Regular RR interval, narrow QRS complexes
- Sawtooth appearance of P waves (flutter waves)

These findings indicate atrial flutter with 4:1 AV block.

E) INCORRECT:

Ablation of the bundle of Kent is performed in the case of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome (WPW syndrome), which can present as recurrent palpitations. However, there is no evidence of ventricular preexcitation on the ECG, such as broad QRS complexes or a delta wave, to suggest WPW syndrome.
Image Description:

Conduction pathways and characteristic ECG findings in normal impulse transmission and in WPW syndrome. Note that the condition is referred to as WPW syndrome only if the characteristic ECG findings are present and the patient is also symptomatic or there is evidence of arrhythmia; if the characteristic ECG findings are present without these additional features, the condition is referred to as “WPW pattern.”

Left (normal impulse transmission and normal ECG findings): PR interval 120–200 ms; QRS duration < 100 ms

Right (WPW impulse transmission and characteristic ECG findings): short PR interval < 120 ms; slurred upstroke (delta wave) at the start of the QRS complex with widened QRS ≥ 120 ms
questions.hint: The ECG findings (i.e., irregular rhythm without P waves) indicate atrial fibrillation (Afib). Ablative procedures should be considered in patients with Afib who remain symptomatic despite medical therapy.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of acute confusion and sudden weakness of her left leg that lasted for about 30 minutes. One hour prior to admission, she was unable to understand words and had slurred speech for about 15 minutes. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. She has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. Current medications include metformin and hydrochlorothiazide. Her pulse is 110/min and irregular; blood pressure is 135/84 mmHg. Examination shows cold extremities. There is a mild bruit heard above the left carotid artery. Cardiac examination shows a grade 2/6 late systolic ejection murmur that begins with a midsystolic click. Neurological and mental status examinations show no abnormalities. ECG shows irregularly spaced QRS complexes with no discernible P waves. Doppler ultrasonography shows mild left carotid artery stenosis. A CT scan and diffusion-weighted MRI of the brain show no abnormalities. Which of the following treatments is most likely to prevent future episodes of neurologic dysfunction in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Atorvastatin is indicated in patients with TIA or ischemic stroke to reduce the risk of recurrence. Moreover, it is indicated in all patients with carotid artery stenosis to prevent progression of the disease. While treatment with a statin should be started in this patient, her TIA was most likely caused by thromboembolism related to atrial fibrillation, which would not be prevented by atorvastatin.

B) INCORRECT:

Enalapril therapy is used to treat hypertension, the most important modifiable risk factor for ischemic stroke. This patient would benefit from better blood pressure management, but her TIA was most likely caused by thromboembolism related to atrial fibrillation. This drug is unlikely to prevent future TIA episodes related to atrial fibrillation.

C) INCORRECT:

Carotid revascularization (e.g., via endarterectomy) is indicated for patients with symptomatic, severe carotid artery stenosis (CAS). It should also be considered for patients with symptomatic, moderate CAS, and asymptomatic patients with severe CAS. This patient has mild CAS and it is unlikely to have caused her TIA. Instead, her TIA is more likely due to a thromboembolic complication of Afib, which would not be prevented by carotid endarterectomy.

D) CORRECT:

A patient with TIA and concomitant Afib on initial presentation should undergo evaluation for anticoagulation to prevent future complications of Afib (e.g., systemic embolization with TIA). In women with Afib and a CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥ 3 (and men with a score ≥ 2), oral anticoagulation with either warfarin or a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC), e.g., rivaroxaban, is indicated. This patient's score is 6 (+1 for age 65–74 years, +1 for female sex category, +1 for history of hypertension, +2 for history of TIA, and +1 for history of diabetes mellitus). DOACs are preferred over warfarin in the long-term management of most patients with atrial fibrillation with an indication for anticoagulation. Exceptions include patients with rheumatic mitral stenosis, mechanical heart valve, and chronic severe kidney disease.

Generally, patients with TIA should receive immediate antiplatelet therapy (e.g., aspirin) unless they have a clear indication for anticoagulation at initial presentation (e.g., Afib). If this is the case, antiplatelet therapy can be replaced with anticoagulation to prevent thromboembolism.

E) INCORRECT:

Aspirin is used as antiplatelet therapy in patients with TIA and should be initiated during the initial evaluation and within 24 hours after symptom onset. If patients have a clear indication for anticoagulation at initial presentation (e.g., Afib), antiplatelet therapy can be replaced with anticoagulation to prevent thromboembolism. More importantly, because it is not an anticoagulant, aspirin therapy is less likely to prevent future neurologic symptoms in this patient with Afib who is at risk of thromboembolism.

F) INCORRECT:

Clopidogrel is used as an antiplatelet agent in patients with TIA or ischemic stroke to reduce the risk of recurrence. However, this drug is ineffective for preventing thromboembolism related to atrial fibrillation because it is not an anticoagulant. In this patient with evidence for a cardioembolic etiology, a different drug is more likely to prevent future neurologic symptoms.
questions.hint: Acute confusion, hemiparesis, and slurred speech are signs of an acute cerebrovascular accident. The full reversal of all neurologic symptoms within 1 hour and absence of signs of ischemia on neuroimaging makes a transient ischemic attack (TIA) very likely in this patient. In addition, this patient has an irregular pulse and, on ECG, irregularly spaced QRS complexes and no distinct P waves, all of which are characteristic findings in atrial fibrillation (Afib).

questions.text: A 69-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of palpitations. She has never experienced these symptoms before. She has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include atorvastatin, lisinopril, and metformin. She does not drink alcohol or smoke cigarettes. Her temperature is 36.2°C (97.2°F), pulse is 72/min and irregular, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 122/88 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Lungs are clear to auscultation. There is no lower extremity edema. Serum electrolyte and thyroid-stimulating hormone concentrations are within the reference ranges. Her serum creatinine is 1.0 mg/dL. An ECG shows indiscernible P waves, irregularly irregular RR intervals, and narrow QRS complexes. Transthoracic echocardiography shows mild atrial enlargement, left ventricular hypertrophy with a preserved ejection fraction of 0.55, and chaotic atrial movements that are not coordinated with the ventricles. No thrombus is visible. The patient is scheduled for elective electrical cardioversion. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diltiazem can be used in patients with Afib when rate control is indicated. The target resting heart rate in Afib is < 110/min for patients who are asymptomatic and < 80/min for patients who are symptomatic. Because this patient has a heart rate of 72/min, diltiazem should not be used.

B) INCORRECT:

Eptifibatide is an antiplatelet medication only used in high-risk patients with unstable angina or NSTEMI to prevent thrombotic complications during percutaneous coronary intervention. This drug is not used in the prevention of thromboembolism, which is what is required for a patient with Afib who is scheduled for elective cardioversion.

C) INCORRECT:

Atenolol can be used in patients with Afib when rate control is indicated. The target resting heart rate for patients with Afib is < 110/min for asymptomatic patients and < 80/min for symptomatic patients. This patient has a heart rate of 72/min and, therefore, should not be given a beta blocker.

D) INCORRECT:

Flecainide may be used in patients with Afib for pharmacological cardioversion, but this patient is already scheduled for electrical cardioversion. Furthermore, flecainide is contraindicated in patients with structural heart disease (e.g., left ventricular hypertrophy, mild atrial enlargement), as the drug is highly proarrhythmic, inducing, e.g., QT prolongation, QRS complex widening, and bradyarrhythmias. In addition to the use for cardioversion, flecainide is also sometimes prescribed to patients with Afib without structural heart disease as part of a pill-in-pocket approach.

E) INCORRECT:

Aspirin is an antiplatelet medication used in the prevention of cardiovascular disease and after acute myocardial infarction, angina pectoris, and acute ischemic stroke. It is not used in the prevention of thromboembolism, which is required for a patient with Afib who is scheduled for elective cardioversion.

F) CORRECT:

Afib can lead to stasis of blood and thrombi formation in the atrium, which, in patients undergoing cardioversion, can get dislodged and cause thromboembolism. Therefore, anticoagulation with a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC) such as apixaban should be initiated prior to cardioversion and continued for ≥ 4 weeks after the procedure in patients with Afib starting in the past 48 hours who have a moderate to high thromboembolic risk, such as this patient. If DOACs are contraindicated, heparin (e.g., for pregnant patients) or warfarin (e.g., for patients with mechanical heart valves) can be used.

In patients with new-onset Afib for > 48 hours or if the duration is unknown, anticoagulation should be given for at least 3 weeks before cardioversion and the need for rate control should be evaluated. The time to cardioversion can be shortened by performing transesophageal echocardiography after therapeutic anticoagulation, as this procedure detects atrial thrombi with greater sensitivity than transthoracic echocardiography.
questions.hint: This patient has new-onset nonvalvular atrial fibrillation (Afib) starting < 48 hours ago with a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 4 (hypertension, age 65–74 years, diabetes mellitus, female sex).

questions.text: A previously healthy 28-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of dizziness and palpitations for 2 days. Prior to the onset of the symptoms, he attended a bachelor party where he lost several drinking games. An ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy is a hereditary disease of the myocardium that is characterized by asymmetric hypertrophy of the left ventricle (LVH). Although it is usually asymptomatic and often an incidental finding, it can cause syncope and/or lethal arrhythmias that lead to sudden cardiac death, typically during periods of physical exertion. In some cases, it can cause palpitations and dizziness as in this patient. However, ECG would show abnormally deep Q waves and signs of LVH (according to the Sokolow-Lyon Index).
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Heart rate: ∼55/min
– Regular sinus rhythm
– Normal cardiac axis: positive (+) QRS complex polarity in leads I, II, and III
– Broad and bifid P waves (P): referred to as “P mitrale” and suggestive of left atrial enlargement
– SV2 (S) + RV5 (R) >3.5 mV: meets Sokolow-Lyon criteria for left ventricular hypertrophy
– Left ventricular strain pattern: ST depression (ST) with T-wave inversion (T) in left-sided leads I and V4–V6

Positive Sokolow-Lyon criteria and left ventricular strain pattern are characteristic of left ventricular hypertrophy.

B) INCORRECT:

Dilated cardiomyopathy is a unilateral or global enlargement of the myocardium, which leads to limited contractility and a subsequent decrease in pumping function. Although the condition could explain this patient's arrhythmia, palpitations, and dizziness, other specific signs of right ventricular failure (e.g., peripheral pitting edema, signs of increased central venous pressure) or left ventricular failure (e.g., pulmonary edema, dyspnea) are not present, making this condition very unlikely.

C) CORRECT:

Atrial fibrillation (Afib) is a supraventricular tachyarrhythmia caused by uncoordinated atrial activation. Although usually asymptomatic, it can also cause symptoms such as dizziness and palpitations. In particular, acute alcohol consumption often triggers paroxysmal Afib (also known as “holiday heart syndrome”), which subsides within 7 days without intervention. To prevent similar episodes, this patient should abstain from alcohol in the future.

D) INCORRECT:

Brugada syndrome is a genetically inherited disorder that causes a repolarization abnormality and occurs more commonly in male individuals of Asian descent. Although it is usually asymptomatic, it can cause palpitations and dizziness, as in this patient, which may also be triggered by substance abuse or alcohol consumption. However, an ECG would show persistent ST elevations in leads V1–V2 with intact P waves.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Regular sinus rhythm
– Heart rate: ∼62/min
– Normal axis: R > S in I and aVF
– First-degree AV block: PR interval ∼240 ms
– Coved ST elevation ≥ 2 mm and a negative T wave in V1 and V2
– Pseudo-RBBB: The ST-changes create a pattern resembling RBBB in V1/V2.

Pseudo-RBBB with ST elevation in V1–V3 is characteristic of Brugada pattern. To diagnose Brugada syndrome, the corresponding clinical criteria must also be met, e.g., VF, syncope, or pertinent family history.

E) INCORRECT:

Ventricular tachycardia is a potentially life-threatening arrhythmia originating in the ventricles and is associated with structural heart disease or myocardial infarction. Although it can manifest with palpitations, which may also be triggered by substance abuse or alcohol consumption, an ECG would show AV dissociation and wide QRS complexes with a heart rate > 120 bpm.
Image Description:

Single-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Rate: 192/min
– Regular rhythm
– No P or T waves are discernible because of the high ventricular rate.
– QRS complexes are broad (> 120 ms) and monomorphic (there is a similar QRS morphology in all beats).

These features are characteristic of monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT). VT persisting for ≥ 30 seconds is considered sustained VT (this strip does not show the full 30-second interval).

F) INCORRECT:

Sick sinus syndrome (SSS) is due to a dysfunctional sinoatrial node that can cause bradyarrhythmias and/or supraventricular tachyarrhythmias. Although it can manifest with an irregular rhythm with narrow QRS complexes and indiscernible P waves, ECG usually also shows sinoatrial pauses or “tachycardia-bradycardia” cycling. In addition, SSS is associated with coronary artery and structural heart diseases. This patient's age, history of a single event, and ECG findings make SSS an unlikely explanation for his symptoms.
Image Description:

Holter monitor 3-lead ECG (paper speed: 25mm/s)

- Sinus rhythm
- Heart rate approx. 75/min
- Normal QRS duration
- 4 sinus pauses of ∼ 1.6 s, followed by normal P wave and normal QRS complex

Temporary absent P waves after preceding atrial depolarization indicates a sinus node dysfunction (sick sinus syndrome).
questions.hint: The ECG shows an irregular rhythm with narrow QRS complexes and indiscernible P waves. Other common triggers of this patient's ECG findings include elevated sympathetic activity (e.g., during stress), hyperthyroidism, caffeine consumption, and mitral valve disease.

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus is brought to the emergency department 60 minutes after the acute onset of left-sided abdominal pain and nausea with vomiting. She underwent emergency surgical revascularization for acute left lower extremity ischemia 3 weeks ago. Physical examination shows left upper quadrant tenderness without rebound or guarding. Serum studies show an elevated lactate dehydrogenase level. Laboratory studies, including a complete blood count, basic metabolic panel, and hepatic panel, show no abnormalities. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen shows a wedge-shaped non-enhancing lesion in the spleen. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Infrarenal aortic aneurysm on abdominal CT scan
Right atrial thrombus on transesophageal echocardiography

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Absent P waves and irregularly irregular RR intervals on electrocardiogram would be consistent with atrial fibrillation (Afib) a significant risk factor for atrial thrombus formation due to the rapid, irregular contraction of the atria and subsequent blood stasis. Thrombi formed in the left atrium or left ventricle can fragment into emboli and disperse into the arterial circulation, leading to ischemic events. This patient has multiple risk factors for Afib, including her age, hypertension, and diabetes.
Image Description:

CT scan of the abdomen (axial view) with intravenous contrast

A wedge-shaped hypoattenuated region (red overlay) is visible within the spleen.

This is characteristic of a splenic infarct.

B) INCORRECT:

Sonographic evidence of a noncompressible femoral vein would be consistent with a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the femoral vein. While the patient's acute limb ischemia and splenic infarction were probably caused by embolic events, the emboli both occurred in the arterial system, whereas DVTs result in occlusion of the venous system. Venous emboli from DVTs can travel to the pulmonary vasculature (resulting in pulmonary embolism) but would not enter the systemic vasculature without the presence of a significant right-to-left shunt (e.g., patent foramen ovale), which is uncommon.

C) INCORRECT:

Infrarenal aortic aneurysms can increase the risk of arterial embolic events at sites distal to the aneurysm, such as the lower extremities. The splenic artery and short gastric vessels supplying the spleen arise from the celiac trunk, which originates above the renal arteries. As a result, the spleen would not be affected by an infrarenal aortic aneurysm.

D) INCORRECT:

A right atrial thrombus could embolize into the pulmonary vasculature, causing pulmonary embolism. However, embolism from a right atrial thrombus into the arterial system would only be possible with a concurrent intra-cardiac shunt (e.g., patent foramen ovale). Given this patient's age and risk factors, a different finding is much more likely to be present.

E) INCORRECT:

Schistocytes may be present on a peripheral blood smear as a result of intravascular hemolysis in conditions such as hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) and thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). Both HUS and TTP can elevate LDH levels and cause splenic infarcts. However, in the absence of further signs of intravascular hemolysis (e.g., anemia, hyperbilirubinemia), HUS and TTP are unlikely causes of the patient's splenic infarction. This patient's elevated LDH level is most likely a direct result of her splenic infarct.
questions.hint: This woman's CT findings and acute onset of left-sided abdominal pain are consistent with acute splenic infarction. In patients < 40 years of age, the underlying cause of splenic infarction is most commonly a hypercoagulable state, whereas the etiology in patients > 40 years of age is most often thromboembolic. This woman has had two different thromboembolic events in the arterial system.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of intermittent chest pain and dizziness on exertion. Her pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 125/82 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows a grade 3/6, late-peaking, crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur heard best over the right upper sternal border. An echocardiogram confirms the diagnosis. Three months later, the patient returns to the physician with palpitations and worsening shortness of breath for 2 weeks. An ECG obtained at the second visit is shown. Based on the abnormality seen on ECG, what is the most likely cause of the acute exacerbation of dyspnea in this patient?

choices.text: Impaired contractility of the right ventricle
Decreased impulse conduction across the AV node

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Severe AS can lead to impaired right ventricular contractility via backward failure. Backward failure can cause dyspnea due to the backup of blood into the lungs. The backup of blood in this patient is caused by impaired contractility of the left rather than the right ventricle. Also, this patient has no features of right ventricular dysfunction, such as pitting edema or jugular venous distention. In patients with AS, exacerbation of dyspnea due to AF is caused by a different mechanism.

B) INCORRECT:

Coronary artery blood flow predominantly occurs during diastole and is driven by the myocardial perfusion pressure gradient. AF causes a decreased, not increased, myocardial perfusion pressure gradient as a result of uncoordinated atrial contraction (which impairs diastolic filling of the left ventricle) and tachycardia (which shortens the duration of diastole). In addition, this patient has AS, which often causes left ventricular hypertrophy. Left ventricular hypertrophy further compromises the myocardial perfusion pressure gradient by impeding diastolic filling.

C) CORRECT:

AS causes increased left ventricular afterload and end-systolic volume, which results in an increase in filling pressures and concentric left ventricular hypertrophy. Because left ventricular hypertrophy commonly results in diastolic dysfunction, individuals with AS rely on the contraction of the left atrium for ventricular filling. The increase in diastolic filling pressure can, in turn, cause left atrial dilatation, which increases the risk of AF. AF decreases left ventricular preload as a result of uncoordinated atrial contraction (which impairs diastolic filling of the left ventricle) and tachycardia (which shortens the duration of diastole and reduces ventricular filling time). If AF develops in individuals with severe AS, it can exacerbate symptoms of angina and dyspnea due to pulmonary edema, which is likely responsible for this patient's worsening shortness of breath.

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased impulse conduction across the AV node occurs in patients with nodal conduction abnormalities, which can cause angina, dizziness, and/or an irregular pulse, depending on the degree of AV block. However, these conditions typically cause bradycardia, and are associated with discernable P waves on ECG. Moreover, none of these conditions is associated with a crescendo-decrescendo murmur.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased systemic vascular resistance (SVR) occurs as part of the compensatory response to maintain tissue perfusion in patients with AS. A stenotic aortic valve reduces cardiac output and leads to hypoperfusion, which results in angina and dizziness. An increase in SVR is not, however, responsible for the acute exacerbation of symptoms, which is most likely related to AF.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur that is best heard over the right upper sternal border, suggesting aortic stenosis (AS). Her ECG shows features of atrial fibrillation (AF), such as irregularly irregular RR intervals, indiscernible P waves, and narrow QRS complexes.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravid woman at 12 weeks’ gestation comes to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of palpitations and lightheadedness. Her pregnancy had been uncomplicated. She has mitral stenosis due to rheumatic heart disease. The patient immigrated from Sudan 11 months ago. Her only medication is a daily multivitamin. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 132/min and irregular, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 115/68 mm Hg. On cardiac examination, a grade 2/6 rumbling mid-diastolic murmur is heard best at the apex; no other abnormalities are noted. Results of complete blood count, serum chemistry profile, and thyroid function tests are within the reference ranges. An ECG is shown. Treatment with low molecular weight heparin is initiated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Adenosine can be used for the termination of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT), which is one of the most common types of arrhythmia in pregnancy and can manifest with palpitations, tachycardia, narrow QRS complexes (< 120 ms), and absent P waves. However, RR intervals and pulse are regular in PSVT.

B) INCORRECT:

Continuous ECG monitoring (i.e., Holter monitoring) for 24–48 hours is used in the following situations: patients with frequent palpitations and/or syncope; if other ambulatory ECG monitoring devices cannot be used; to assess the effect of rate control in Afib; or to screen for ventricular ectopy in high-risk patients (e.g., those with cardiomyopathy, acute coronary syndrome). Although this patient reports palpitations, an ECG has already revealed Afib and she is not taking any rate control medication (e.g., beta blockers, calcium channel blockers, digoxin) that needs to be evaluated for efficacy.

C) CORRECT:

Rhythm control with cardioversion is a treatment approach used for some patients with new-onset Afib (e.g., young and/or pregnant patients) and aims to restore sinus rhythm in order to prevent atrial remodeling and improve symptoms. However, prolonged episodes of Afib significantly increase the risk of atrial thrombi formation and subsequent dislodgement during cardioversion. Therefore, hemodynamically stable patients who have had Afib for ≥ 48 hours or an unknown period of time require systemic anticoagulation for 3 weeks prior to cardioversion. If cardioversion is desired earlier (e.g., in pregnant and/or symptomatic patients), the time to cardioversion can be shortened by performing transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) to detect potential thrombi and guide further management.

TEE is not required prior to cardioversion in hemodynamically unstable patients with Afib, as the risk of complications from hemodynamic instability outweighs the risk of thromboembolic complications after cardioversion.

The management of hemodynamically stable, symptomatic patients with Afib with rapid ventricular response usually also includes rate control (e.g., with a beta blocker) as one of the first steps in management. Although this patient may be considered for rate control, TEE is the most appropriate answer given the options provided in this question.

D) INCORRECT:

Electrical cardioversion should be performed immediately in patients with hemodynamically unstable tachycardia with a pulse, including patients with Afib. It may also be considered in some hemodynamically stable patients with episodes of new-onset Afib lasting < 48 hours. However, another step in management is warranted prior to cardioversion in patients who have had Afib for ≥ 48 hours.

E) INCORRECT:

Warfarin can be used as an anticoagulation treatment option for patients with Afib to bridge the time until cardioversion. However, warfarin should be avoided during the first trimester because it crosses the placenta, which can cause teratogenicity and fetal bleeding. Low molecular weight heparin is the preferred agent for pregnant patients.

F) INCORRECT:

Pharmacological cardioversion can be used for rhythm control in hemodynamically stable patients with new-onset Afib. However, another step in management is warranted prior to cardioversion in patients who have had Afib for ≥ 48 hours. Furthermore, pharmacological cardioversion is not the preferred method of rhythm control in pregnant patients.
questions.hint: This patient's absent P waves and irregularly irregular rhythm on ECG indicate atrial fibrillation (Afib), which is a common complication in patients with mitral stenosis.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her partner because of palpitations. She says that her heart “has been racing” for the past 3 hours. The patient and her partner were at a techno rave party before her symptoms started and they both took ecstasy. She works as a sales manager at a pharmaceutical company; she has been under a lot of stress lately and has been sleeping poorly. She reports that she “just wanted to blow off some steam”. She is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min and irregularly irregular, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 127/71 mm Hg. Physical examination shows mydriasis and mild diaphoresis. ECG shows absent P waves. The patient is admitted to the hospital for observation. Follow-up ECG 2 hours later shows normal P waves and narrow QRS complexes. She says that she feels better but still feels occasional palpitations. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Administration of an IV bolus of adenosine causes a transient AV node block that can terminate acute supraventricular tachycardias. It can also be used to unmask underlying Afib or atrial flutter in supraventricular tachyarrhythmias. However, adenosine is not effective in terminating Afib. Moreover, this patient has converted to sinus rhythm.

B) INCORRECT:

In nonvalvular Afib, which this patient most likely has, anticoagulation should be initiated based on the CHA2DS2-VASc score. Since this patient has a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 1, which is considered low risk for stroke in women, anticoagulation is not required.

C) INCORRECT:

Beta blockers (e.g., metoprolol) are the first-line therapeutic agents for rate control in Afib. They normalize ventricular rate and reduce symptoms. However, since this patient spontaneously converted to sinus rhythm, a rate control strategy is not indicated at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

In new-onset Afib, emergency electrical cardioversion should be performed in hemodynamically unstable patients, or elective electrical cardioversion might be performed in hemodynamically stable patients, in an attempt to restore sinus rhythm. This patient, however, is hemodynamically stable and spontaneously converted to sinus rhythm, making electrical cardioversion unnecessary.

E) CORRECT:

This patient initially presented with what was presumed to be new-onset symptomatic Afib. While controlling rate and/or rhythm, as well as providing anticoagulation (according to CHA2DS2-VASc score), are the key therapeutic principles in this condition, the patient's spontaneous conversion to sinus rhythm and her CHA2DS2-VASc score of 1 indicate that no further management (i.e., medical or electrophysiological intervention), aside from observation, is necessary at this time. Nonetheless, underlying causes of Afib (such as structural heart disease, hyperthyroidism, electrolyte imbalances) should be investigated.

F) INCORRECT:

Catheter ablation of ectopic foci and pulmonary vein isolation is a long-term therapeutic option for patients with symptomatic refractory Afib or atrial flutter. In a new-onset Afib that has spontaneously reverted, as is the case here, catheter ablation is not indicated.
questions.hint: This patient initially presented with palpitations, an irregularly irregular pulse, and absent P waves on ECG, which is consistent with new-onset atrial fibrillation (Afib). Amphetamine use, lack of sleep, and stress are possible triggers of arrhythmia. The follow-up ECG taken two hours later showed normal P waves, which indicates a conversion to sinus rhythm.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 2-hour history of palpitations and lightheadedness. He has no chest pain or dyspnea. He has hypertension treated with lisinopril. He is 183 cm (6 ft 0 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb); BMI is 30 kg/m2. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 150/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mm Hg. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Atrial flutter most commonly develops as a result of a macroreentrant circuit within the right atria that travels along the tricuspid annulus and passes through the cavotricuspid isthmus. Although the exact etiology remains unclear, a number of risk factors such as hypertension and obesity are known to contribute. Most patients with atrial flutter are asymptomatic, but symptoms of arrhythmia such as palpitations, lightheadedness, syncope, and dyspnea can also develop. The ECG typically shows a regular rhythm, sawtooth P waves, and possibly a concomitant atrioventricular block with a fixed pattern (2:1 in this case). Stable patients who do not convert spontaneously to sinus rhythm should usually undergo pharmacological or electrical cardioversion. A common complication of atrial flutter is progression to atrial fibrillation. Because the risk of thromboembolism in atrial flutter is similarly elevated as in atrial fibrillation, the indications for anticoagulation are the same.

B) INCORRECT:

Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) can manifest with symptoms of arrhythmia (e.g., palpitations, lightheadedness) and an irregularly irregular rhythm with abnormal P waves on ECG. However, the P waves seen in MAT characteristically have at least three different morphologies and there are distinct isoelectric intervals between P waves.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Heart rate ∼ 160/min
– Irregularly irregular rhythm with wide variation in RR intervals (overlay) and variable PP, PR, and QT intervals
– ≥ P wave morphologies in the same lead (marked in rhythm strip II: normal, inverted, biphasic)
– Isoelectric baseline between P waves
– Narrow QRS complexes with similar morphology throughout

An irregularly irregular tachycardia with an isoelectric baseline and ≥ 3 distinct P wave morphologies in a single lead is consistent with multifocal atrial tachycardia.

C) INCORRECT:

Atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia can manifest with symptoms of arrhythmia (e.g., palpitations, lightheadedness). However, an ECG typically shows a regular heart rhythm, narrow QRS complexes, absent P waves (hidden in the QRS complexes), and a heart rate of 150–220/min.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Regular rhythm; heart rate ∼190/min.
– Normal cardiac axis (R > S in leads I and aVF)
– Narrow QRS complexes (< 100 ms)
– No visible P waves (they are buried in the QRS complexes)
– Widespread ST segment depression, most prominent in V3–V5 (likely rate-related; indicated by red overlay)
– QRS alternans: QRS amplitude is normal throughout but oscillates (indicated by green line)

A regular, narrow-complex tachycardia without visible P-waves is characteristic of AVNRT. Rate-related ST depression and QRS alternans are also commonly observed.

D) INCORRECT:

Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome can manifest with symptoms of arrhythmia (e.g., palpitations, lightheadedness), and a heart rate of > 250/min. However, an ECG typically shows regular short PR intervals, delta waves, and wide QRS complexes, none of which is seen here.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Heart rate: ∼65/min
– Sinus rhythm
– Normal cardiac axis (R > S in I and aVF)
– Widened QRS complexes (∼ 140 ms)
– Short PR intervals (∼ 100 ms)
– Delta wave (most visible in leads II, V5 and V6, example indicated by blue overlay in V5 zoombox)

A short PR interval and widened QRS complexes with delta waves are the characteristic ECG findings of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Atrial fibrillation (Afib) can manifest with symptoms of arrhythmia (e.g., palpitations, lightheadedness). Furthermore, hypertension and obesity are risk factors for Afib. However, an ECG typically shows irregularly irregular RR-intervals, indiscernible P waves, and the heart rate typically ranges between 100 and 180/min.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Irregularly irregular rhythm (examples of the irregular R-R intervals are indicated by red arrows)

– Average ventricular rate ∼ 84/min (14 QRS complexes can be seen on the 10-second rhythm strip)

– No discernable P waves

– Narrow QRS complexes (examples indicated by green lines)

– Normal cardiac axis

These findings are characteristic of atrial fibrillation.
questions.hint: The ECG shows an atrial rate of approx. 300/min and a sawtooth P wave morphology best seen in leads II, III, and aVF.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old man with hypertension, hyperlipidemia, obesity, type 2 diabetes, and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation presents for a new-patient visit. He feels well and has no complaints. His current medications include metformin 1000 mg twice daily, metoprolol extended-release 75 mg once daily, lisinopril 20 mg once daily, simvastatin 20 mg once daily, and aspirin 325 mg daily. He has no history of stroke or ischemic heart disease.
His blood pressure is 128/80 mm Hg. His pulse is irregularly irregular, but his examination is otherwise unremarkable.
An electrocardiogram reveals atrial fibrillation with a ventricular rate of 88 beats per minute.
His calculated 10-year risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease is 4.9%.
Which one of the following long-term antithrombotic approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Stop aspirin, and start apixaban 5 mg twice daily
Reduce aspirin to 81 mg daily, and start clopidogrel 75 mg daily
Reduce aspirin to 81 mg daily, and start warfarin with a target international normalized ratio of 2.0 to 3.0
Stop aspirin, and start clopidogrel 75 mg daily

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The CHA2 DS2-VASc score is commonly used to stratify patients with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation according to their risk for thromboembolism. The score’s component risk factors are as follows:

• C ongestive heart failure (any history)
• H ypertension (blood pressure persistently >140/90 mm Hg or current antihypertensive therapy)
• A ge ≥75 years
• D iabetes mellitus
• S troke (history of stroke or transient ischemic attack [TIA])
• V ascular disease (previous myocardial infarction, peripheral vascular disease, or aortic disease)
• A ge 65 to 74 years
• Female S ex

Each risk factor is assigned 1 point, except for stroke or TIA and age ≥75 years, which are each assigned 2 points. The points are summed to arrive at the CHA2 DS2-VASc score, with a high score corresponding to a greater risk for stroke and a low score corresponding to a lower risk.

Anticoagulation recommendations according to the CHA2 DS2-VASc score differ by sex. Women get 1 point based on their sex alone, but female sex only increases thrombotic risk in the presence of other risk factors. Therefore, the cutoff scores for anticoagulant therapy are 1 point higher for women than for men. The recommendations are as follows:

• A score of 0 for men or 1 for women (indicating low risk for stroke) does not merit anticoagulant therapy.
• A score of 1 for men or 2 for women (indicating intermediate risk for stroke) may merit consideration of anticoagulant therapy, depending on the risk of bleeding associated with therapy. It should be noted that guidelines from different organizations differ on this point; for example, the European Society of Cardiology guidelines recommend anticoagulation for men with a score of 1. Of note, aspirin is no longer recommended as an option in this patient group.
• A score ≥ 2 for men or ≥ 3 for women (indicating high risk for stroke) merits management with oral anticoagulation, assuming no contraindications.

Given that this male patient has a CHA2 DS2-VASc score of 2 (because of his diabetes and hypertension), oral anticoagulation should be initiated. A direct oral anticoagulant is typically recommended, although warfarin would be the preferred agent if the patient had moderate-to-severe mitral stenosis or a mechanical heart valve. The fact that the atrial fibrillation is paroxysmal (rather than permanent) does not change the anticoagulant recommendations.

Key learning point: Men with atrial fibrillation and a CHA2 DS2-VASc score ≥2 should be treated with oral anticoagulation; the cutoff score for such therapy in women is ≥3.

B) INCORRECT:

Clopidogrel, with or without aspirin, is inferior to warfarin for stroke prevention in patients with atrial fibrillation. In addition, combination therapy with antiplatelet agents and anticoagulation therapy is associated with a much higher bleeding risk and is therefore rarely appropriate except in high-risk patients.

C) INCORRECT:

Warfarin would be the preferred agent if the patient had moderate-to-severe mitral stenosis or a mechanical heart valve. In addition, combination therapy with antiplatelet agents and anticoagulation therapy is associated with a much higher bleeding risk and is therefore rarely appropriate except in high-risk patients.

D) INCORRECT:

Given that this patient has no history of ischemic heart disease or stroke, he was presumably using aspirin for primary cardiovascular prevention. In patients with diabetes mellitus, the data on the effectiveness of low-dose (75–162 mg) aspirin for primary prevention is lacking; most trials have failed to consistently show a significant reduction in cardiovascular end points. As a result, the American Diabetes Association recommends considering aspirin for primary prevention in those with diabetes mellitus who are at increased cardiovascular risk — but only after a discussion with the patient about the benefits of the therapy versus the increased risk of bleeding. Generally, aspirin can be considered for patients whose 10-year risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease is >10%. In this patient whose risk is <5%, aspirin is not indicated for primary prevention.

E) INCORRECT:

Clopidogrel, with or without aspirin, is inferior to warfarin for stroke prevention in patients with atrial fibrillation.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man is diagnosed with Graves disease, and treatment with methimazole is initiated. Four weeks later, he develops palpitations, sweating, and frequent bowel movements, despite taking the methimazole as prescribed. He has no other significant medical history, including heart failure, stroke, vascular disease, or diabetes mellitus.
His heart rate is 112 beats per minute and irregularly irregular, and his blood pressure is 116/78 mm Hg. His skin is sweaty, and he has a visible resting tremor. His thyroid is smoothly enlarged and is nontender. No proptosis is noted.
An electrocardiogram is obtained (figure).
In addition to a beta-blocker, what additional medication, if any, should be prescribed for this patient?

choices.text: Warfarin, with a target international normalized ratio of 2.0 to 3.0

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Evidence suggests that embolic risk in patients with thyrotoxicosis and atrial fibrillation is not necessarily increased independent of other stroke risk factors. Older guidelines had suggested routine anticoagulation for hyperthyroid patients with atrial fibrillation, but a 2014 guideline from the American College of Cardiology and American Heart Association (ACC/AHA) recommends anticoagulation for such patients only if it is otherwise indicated according to CHA2 DS2-VASc risk factors.

The CHA2 DS2-VASc risk factors are as follows:

• C ongestive heart failure (any history)
• H ypertension (blood pressure persistently >140/90 mm Hg or current antihypertensive therapy)
• A ge ≥75 years
• D iabetes mellitus
• S troke (history of stroke or transient ischemic attack [TIA])
• V ascular disease (previous myocardial infarction, peripheral vascular disease, or aortic disease)
• A ge 65 to 74 years
• Female S ex

Each risk factor is assigned 1 point, except for stroke or TIA and age ≥75 years, which are each assigned 2 points. The points are summed to arrive at the CHA2 DS2-VASc score, with a high score corresponding to a greater risk for stroke and a low score corresponding to a lower risk.

This patient has a CHA2 DS2-VASc risk score of 0 (i.e., low risk of thromboembolic events). For men with a score of 0 or women with a score of 1, no antithrombotic therapy is recommended, according to the latest ACC/AHA guideline.

Anticoagulation can be considered selectively for men with a CHA2 DS2-VASc risk score of 1 and women with a score of 2 — and is recommended for all men with a score ≥2 and women with a score ≥3. Direct oral anticoagulants are the preferred agents, although warfarin is recommended in patients with moderate-to-severe mitral stenosis or a mechanical heart valve.

Key learning point: No anticoagulation therapy is necessary in a patient who has atrial fibrillation associated with hyperthyroidism and no other thromboembolic risk factors.

B) INCORRECT:

Ticagrelor is not the treatment of choice to prevent thromboembolism in patients with atrial fibrillation, especially those with a CHA2 DS2-VASc risk score of 0.

C) INCORRECT:

Anticoagulation can be considered selectively for men with a CHA2 DS2-VASc risk score of 1 and women with a score of 2 — and is recommended for all men with a score ≥2 and women with a score ≥3. Direct oral anticoagulants are the preferred agents, although warfarin is recommended in patients with moderate-to-severe mitral stenosis or a mechanical heart valve. However, this patient has a CHA2 DS2-VASc risk score of 0 and does not require anticoagulation.

D) INCORRECT:

Low-molecular-weight heparin is appropriate for patients with new-onset atrial fibrillation who have a thromboembolic event or a thrombus demonstrated on an echocardiogram; it is not recommended for atrial fibrillation in patients with a CHA2 DS2-VASc risk score of 0.

E) INCORRECT:

Aspirin is no longer recommended for prevention of thromboembolic events in patients with atrial fibrillation.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old man presents with cough, shortness of breath, and palpitations. He is an active smoker and has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. His temperature is 38.1°C, his heart rate is 92 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is 132/80 mm Hg. Pulmonary examination reveals crackles in the right lower lobe. An electrocardiogram documents sinus rhythm with features of left ventricular hypertrophy. A chest radiograph shows a possible infiltrate in the right lower lobe.
During his evaluation, the patient develops tachycardia, prompting a 12-lead electrocardiogram (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is accurate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Although this patient’s initial electrocardiogram showed sinus rhythm, his repeat electrocardiogram reveals a regular, narrow-complex tachycardia at a rate of about 150 beats per minute. Atrial “flutter” waves, with their characteristic well-organized saw-tooth pattern (i.e., no clear isoelectric baseline), are noted at a rate of approximately 300 beats per minute. These features are classic for atrial flutter with 2:1 conduction, which in this case may have been precipitated by the patient’s pneumonia.

Key learning point: A tachyarrhythmia with an atrial rate of 280–300 beats per minute and 2:1 conduction through the atrioventricular node, resulting in a ventricular rate of about 150 beats per minute, is characteristic of atrial flutter.

B) INCORRECT:

Unlike atrial flutter, atrial fibrillation and multifocal atrial tachycardia are both irregularly irregular rhythms.

C) INCORRECT:

Unlike atrial flutter, atrial fibrillation and multifocal atrial tachycardia are both irregularly irregular rhythms.

D) INCORRECT:

Orthodromic atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia and atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia are both regular narrow-complex tachycardias with retrograde P waves falling within or after the QRS complex and a typical ventricular rate of 120 to 220 beats per minute.

E) INCORRECT:

Orthodromic atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia and atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia are both regular narrow-complex tachycardias with retrograde P waves falling within or after the QRS complex and a typical ventricular rate of 120 to 220 beats per minute.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man with no known medical history presents to the emergency department after an episode of syncope that was preceded by several minutes of palpitations and lightheadedness.
A friend who witnessed the event reports that the patient was unresponsive for approximately 30 seconds. No seizure activity was noted. The patient had no bowel or bladder incontinence, and he does not appear to have been injured.
